The sum of the angles in triangle \(ABC\) gives:
   \[
   2y + x = 180^\circ
   \]

text:
The exterior angle theorem states that \(\angle BCD\) (the exterior angle at \(C\)) is equal to the sum of the remote interior angles \(\angle BAC\) and \(\angle ABC\):
   \[
   110^\circ = y + x
   \]
3.
class-1-reason: This paragraph carries out the main algebraic process of solving for the variables using equations derived from angle properties, following solution steps in a logical way without checking or digression—it's direct problem-solving.
class-2-reason: The sentence applies the exterior angle theorem and sets up a relevant equation, clearly an analytical inference using known theorems.

text:
Solving the system of equations:
   \[
   \begin{cases}
   2y + x = 180^\circ \\
   y + x = 110^\circ
   \end{cases}
   \]
   Subtract the second equation from the first:
   \[
   (2y + x) - (y + x) = 180^\circ - 110^\circ \implies y = 70^\circ
   \]
4.

   70^\circ + x = 110^\circ \implies x = 40^\circ
   \]
